item.title: Death Toll of Russian Strike in Dnipro Rises to 40, Ukraine Says
item.description: The authorities said 34 people remained missing after three days of searching for the living and the dead at an apartment building struck by a Russian missile in Dnipro.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers clearing rubble on Monday as they looked for victims of a Russian attack on an apartment building in Dnipro.

item.title: Covid Workers in China Clash With Police Over Unpaid Wages, Layoffs
item.description: Companies that reaped windfalls helping the government implement strict ‘zero Covid’ controls are now struggling to pay and keep workers.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Muyi Xiao

item.title: Matteo Messina Denaro, Italian Mafia Boss, Is Arrested
item.description: Matteo Messina Denaro, who was sentenced in absentia for the 1992 murders of two prosecutors and other crimes, was apprehended at a Sicilian hospital.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse, via Ufficio Stampa Comando Generale
item.media:description: Matteo Messina Denaro, right, in a police vehicle on Monday after his arrest in Palermo, Sicily. He had been wanted since June 1993.

item.title: U.K. Government Blocks Scottish Law Making Gender Change Easier
item.description: For the first time, the government in London is blocking legislation approved by the Scottish Parliament, saying the measure on gender identity would undermine U.K.-wide equality law.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of Scotland’s new gender recognition legislation rallying outside the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh in December, before a debate on the bill.

item.title: Death Toll in Apartment Strike Rises to 40
item.description: Russia’s attack on an apartment complex in Dnipro on Saturday was one of the deadliest for civilians away from the front line since the war began, and came as Western support for Ukraine escalates.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Valda Kalnina/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: British soldiers on a Challenger 2 tank at a training exercise in Latvia in 2020.

item.title: In Nepal Crash, Pilot Met the Same Fate as Her Husband 17 Years Before
item.description: Anju Khatiwada, who died on Sunday in a crash in Pokhara, Nepal, decided to become a pilot after her husband’s death in 2006. The family’s calamities are part of a deadly pattern of aviation disasters in Nepal.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Prakash Mathema/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescuers on Monday recovering the body of a victim who died in a Yeti Airlines plane crash in Pokhara, Nepal, the day before. Seventy-two people were on the flight.

item.title: What 70 Years of War Can Tell Us About the Russia-Ukraine Conflict
item.description: Despite some postmodern features, the fighting resembles a type of conflict from decades past: wars fought between nations in which one does not conquer the other outright.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians firing last week into the Russian-controlled town of Pisky, Ukraine.

item.title: London Police Officer Admits to 49 Charges of Sexual Abuse, Including Rape
item.description: David Carrick, who worked for the Metropolitan Police, carried out “a relentless campaign” of violence over 17 years, prosecutors said, using his position of authority to manipulate victims.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Officials at a news conference outside a London court on Monday after David Carrick, a former police officer, had pleaded guilty to sexual offenses against 12 women.

item.title: Hunting for Truffles Is a Perilous Pursuit, Especially for the Dogs Who Dig
item.description: Truffles are big business, and some are trying to take out the competition by poisoning the dogs that accompany those known as “truffle hunters.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Stephanie Gengotti for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renato Tomassetti and Bella after she found a truffle. “Black gold,” Mr. Tomassetti said.

item.title: Former Afghan Lawmaker Shot Dead at Her Home in Kabul
item.description: The legislator, Mursal Nabizada, was one of a few female parliamentarians who remained in the country after the Western-backed government collapsed and the Taliban seized power.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Wakil Kohsar/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mursal Nabizada, a former Afghan lawmaker, was shot dead by gunmen at her house in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: European Parliament Focuses on 2 More Lawmakers in Corruption Scandal
item.description: The assembly on Monday began the process of lifting the immunity of two members at the request of the Belgian police in a snowballing corruption investigation involving Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Julien Warnand/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: “The events of last months have led to a need to rebuild trust of the European citizens that we represent,” Roberta Metsola, the president of the European Parliament, told lawmakers on Monday at a session in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Chinese ‘Zero Covid’ Workers Revolt
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: UK Confirms Plan to Send Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The U.K. defense secretary said specialty guns, ammunition, drones and other equipment were also part of the package being sent to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Ints Kalnins/Reuters
item.media:description: British Challenger 2 tanks during NATO exercises in Adazi, Latvia, in 2019.

item.title: U.N. Confirms More Than 7,000 Civilian Deaths in Ukraine
item.description: The total includes only those that U.N. investigators have been able to corroborate, and does not include the dozens killed in Saturday’s strike on Dnipro.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bodies of five victims of the missile strike in Dnipro, Ukraine, after being retrieved on Sunday.

item.title: Hamas Releases Video That Appears to Show Israeli Missing Since 2014
item.description: If verified as authentic, the footage would provide the first public proof of life of Avera Mengistu, an Israeli citizen who disappeared after walking into Gaza and had been held captive by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Tsafrir Abayov/Associated Press
item.media:description: A banner showing the captive Israeli civilian Avera Mengistu, left picture, near the Erez border crossing on the Israel-Gaza border, last year.

item.title: Armed Insurgents Kidnap 50 Women in Burkina Faso
item.description: The women were abducted while searching for food in a region that has been under a blockade by extremist groups for nearly a year.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Luc Gnago/Reuters
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling in the Sahel area in 2019 in Burkina Faso.

item.title: Christine Lambrecht Resigns as Germany’s Defense Minister
item.description: Christine Lambrecht was a frequent target of criticism, including over German caution on military aid to Ukraine. Chancellor Olaf Scholz had backed her strongly, and may find her hard to replace.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Odd Andersen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Christine Lambrecht, the departing defense minister, is the most senior official to have resigned from Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government.

item.title: A united Europe weathers crises, but deeper challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Families boarding evacuation trains last February in Kramatorsk, Ukraine. Europe is divided about how the war in Ukraine should end.

item.title: Russia is pulling off the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn

item.title: Putin’s Wins and Losses
item.description: Ukraine’s winter slowed the war, but there have been major developments.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The large residential building in Dnipro, that was hit by a missile on Saturday.

item.title: The war in Ukraine upended energy markets. What does that mean for the climate?
item.description: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carrying food and water supplies through the village of Posad-Pokrovske, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: Germany’s defense minister resigns after criticism over her handling of the war.
item.description: The minister was repeatedly attacked over public blunders and her handling of the war in Ukraine. She is the most senior member of Olaf Scholz’s government to resign.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Martin Divisek/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Christine Lambrecht resigned as Germany’s defense minister.

item.title: Britain leads a push for more Western military aid to Ukraine, and soon.
item.dc:creator: Vivek Shankar and Juston Jones
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain with NATO troops at a military base in Estonia in December.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A search for survivors after a Russian strike on a residential building.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene after a missile struck a residential building in Dnipro.

item.title: In Swiss Alps, Some Wonder What a Future Without Snow May Mean
item.description: An unusually warm winter has forced a rethink about climate change in areas with lower peaks as ski resorts and sporting events face an uncertain future.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Sattel, Switzerland, tufts of grass broke through the patchy snow on the slopes this winter amid high temperatures.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: A Fatal Plane Crash in Nepal
item.description: Also a major attack in Ukraine, Japan’s military ambitions and a preview of the Australian Open.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Naresh Giri, via Reuters
item.media:description: A plane carrying 72 people crashed in Pokhara, Nepal, killing dozens.

item.title: When Being European Parliament President Includes Aiding Police Raids
item.description: Roberta Metsola, the youngest person to become president of the European Parliament, is seeking to expand the assembly’s role while guiding it through the aftermath of major bribery accusations.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ksenia Kuleshova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roberta Metsola, the president of the European Parliament, is pushing for a slew of transparency measures at the legislature.

item.title: Biden’s Goals on Northern Ireland Present Challenges for Sunak
item.description: The American president wants Britain’s squabble with Europe over Northern Ireland trade issues settled before the 25th anniversary of the peace accord that ended sectarian violence in the North.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Graffiti next to a supermarket in Belfast last April encouraging shoppers not to buy goods from the European Union or Ireland.

item.title: Israel Moves Right
item.description: Israel’s new right-wing government is moving quickly to transform the country.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times

item.title: Dead, Alive or Devastated After Russian Strike on Apartments
item.description: Rescue workers were still digging through the ruins of a residential building in the central Ukrainian city of Dnipro on Sunday, a day after a Russian missile attack.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Firefighters searching through the rubble on Sunday after a missile struck a residential building in Dnipro, Ukraine, a day earlier.

item.title: For Families and Detainees in Russian-Occupied Areas, a Grim Wait
item.description: After Russia’s retreat from Kherson city, Ukrainians in other occupied areas of the south had expectations of quickly regaining their freedom. But those hopes have been dashed.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage in Kherson, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: At Least 68 Dead After Plane Crashes in Nepal
item.description: A twin-engine propeller plane crashed on approach to the city of Pokhara, with 72 people on board.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Krishna Mani Baral/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescue workers inspecting wreckage at the site of the plane crash in Pokhara on Monday.

item.title: ‘I’m Sorry, We’re From Moscow.’ In Bali, Warring Sides Learn to Cohabitate
item.description: Thousands of Russians and Ukrainians have fled their homelands for Bali. But even in a tropical paradise, the war is ever-present.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Nyimas Laula
item.media:description: The entrance to Parq Ubud in Bali, which has become a popular place to live and work for the Russians and Ukrainians who have fled to Indonesia.

item.title: Britain Says It Will Give Ukraine Tanks, Breaching a Western Taboo
item.description: Western countries have balked at giving Ukraine tanks and other powerful weapons. As increased spring fighting looms, that seems to be changing.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Omar Marques/Getty Images
item.media:description: A British Challenger main battle tank during a military exercise in eastern Poland last September. Challenger IIs could become the first Western-made battle tanks to be sent to Ukraine.

item.title: Thousands in Israel Protest Netanyahu’s Plans to Limit Courts
item.description: The right-wing government’s proposals for sweeping judicial reform are viewed by critics as anti-democratic and have galvanized the opposition.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Ilan Rosenberg/Reuters
item.media:description: An estimated 80,000 protesters demonstrated against the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis to Face Off In Czech Republic Presidential Race
item.description: Both candidates, Petr Pavel and Andrej Babis, are expected to foster closer ties to the West.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Petr David Josek/Associated Press
item.media:description: Voting in the Czech presidential elections in Pruhonice on Friday.

item.title: Rescuers rush to save people buried in rubble of a building destroyed by a Russian missile.
item.description: A 15-year-old girl was among the 14 people killed. The search for survivors continues.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Tung, Megan Specia and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: The Saturday morning attack on Kyiv appeared to best the air-raid warning system.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Sergei Karpukhin/Reuters
item.media:description: A Russian Iskander tactical missile system in 2015.

item.title: China Reports Nearly 60,000 Covid-Linked Deaths Since Lifting Restrictions
item.description: The unexpected disclosure was made as the country faces mounting criticism for providing unreliable data on its latest coronavirus outbreak.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Olivia Wang
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A hospital in Shanghai this month. There have been widespread scenes of overflowing hospitals in the country in recent weeks.

item.title: Cinema Studies
item.description: Awards season has begun. It’s time to cram.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: The Dessert-First Author Whose Books Defined Canada’s Treats
item.description: Jean Paré, the prolific, self-published cookbook writer, died last month in Alberta. Her unfussy recipes found an audience with millions of Canadians.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: via Amanda Lovig Hagg
item.media:description: Jean Paré, one of the best-selling cookbook authors in the world, sold more than 30 million cookbooks by the time she retired in 2011.

item.title: As Russians Steal Ukraine’s Art, They Attack Its Identity, Too
item.description: Russian forces have looted tens of thousands of pieces, including avant-garde oil paintings and Scythian gold. Experts say it is the biggest art heist since the Nazis in World War II, intended to strip Ukraine of its cultural heritage.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Oleksandra Mykolyshyn
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the few remaining sculptures in the Kherson Regional Art Museum, which curators say Russian forces spent several days looting last year.

item.title: Cooperation on Climate Is Emerging in the Middle East
item.description: After the Abraham Accords, partnerships between companies in Israel and Arab countries have led to the kinds of initiatives that will be on the Davos agenda.
item.dc:creator: David Kaufman
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:credit: Andrea Dicenzo/Getty Images
item.media:description: Khalid Al Hai, an ExecuJet Middle East board member, right, giving Rabbi Levi Duchman a tour of the luxury jet charter service’s private terminal at Dubai International Airport. The Abraham Accords have led to increased dealings between Israel and Arab countries.

item.title: Ecuador Moves to Expand Drilling in the Amazon
item.description: A novel idea to leave the country’s vast oil reserves in the ground fizzled for lack of international support. Now, struggling under painful debt, the government wants to expand drilling in the rainforest.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn, Manuela Andreoni and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: The failure of that plan led to the expansion of drilling in Block 43.

item.title: Davos Is a Winter Haven, Even With the Crowds
item.description: Many tourist spots are shut down or blocked off during the World Economic Forum, yet there’s still plenty to do amid the clear air and mountain vistas.
item.dc:creator: Lindsey Tramuta
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: In Davos, Swizterland, skiers have access to nearly 167 miles of slopes and 80 different downhill runs spanning five (unlinked) mountain areas.

item.title: A United Europe Weathers Crises, but Deeper Challenges Remain
item.description: Differences on NATO and E.U. enlargement, energy and climate, and relationships with the United States, China, Russia and Ukraine will prime Davos talks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Tyler Hicks/The New York Times
item.media:description: Families boarding evacuation trains last February in Kramatorsk, Ukraine. Europe is divided about how the war in Ukraine should end.

item.title: World Economic Forum in Davos Confronts a New Order
item.description: The Covid-19 pandemic, invasion of Ukraine, trend toward autocracy and economic inequalities challenge the World Economic Forum’s relevance.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Ton Molina/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, and members of the security forces clashed in Brasília on Jan. 8.

item.title: What Does the War in Ukraine Mean for the Climate?
item.description: Almost a year after Russia launched its invasion, assessing the impact on the oil industry and greenhouse gas goals is not so simple.
item.dc:creator: David Gelles
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians walking through the village of Posad-Pokrovske. Beyond the suffering and destruction inflicted on Ukraine, one of the war’s most profound impacts has been on global energy markets and the fight against climate change.

item.title: As Humanitarian Crises Escalate, So Do Demands to End Them
item.description: David Miliband, head of the International Rescue Committee, says the global refugee crisis “is manageable, not insoluble.”
item.dc:creator: Claudia Dreifus
item.media:credit: Badru Katumba/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Refugees from the Democratic Republic of Congo waiting for lunch at a transit center in Uganda in June. Thousands have fled into Uganda amid violent clashes in Congo.

item.title: German Village at Center of a Fight Over Coal and Climate Is Cleared Out
item.description: For years, activists tried to save tiny Lützerath from being razed to make way for the expansion of an open-pit coal mine. This past week, the police moved them out.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:credit: Ingmar Nolting for The New York Times
item.media:description: An excavator removed protesters’ barricades as part of the clearing of Lützerath, Germany, on Wednesday.

item.title: Iran Executes Alireza Akbari, Ex-Official Accused of Spying
item.description: Alireza Akbari, previously a senior military and defense official, had moved to Britain a decade ago. He had been detained since 2019.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Khabar Online, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Alireza Akbari in an undated photo. He was former defense minister in Iran and a dual citizen of Iran and Britain.

item.title: Bolsonaro Faces Investigation for Inspiring Brazil’s Capital Riot
item.description: Brazil’s Supreme Court said it would investigate Jair Bolsonaro, the country’s former president, for inspiring the mob that stormed the nation’s halls of power on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s former president, speaking to supporters at a rally in October ahead of an election later that month that he lost.

item.title: Biden Administration Faces Resistance to Plan to Sell F-16s to Turkey
item.description: The State Department has contacted Congress about major arms deals for Turkey and Greece, but a prominent senator is strongly opposed to the Ankara sale.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Paulo Whitaker/Reuters
item.media:description: The $20 billion arms package for Turkey would include 40 new F-16 fighter jets.

item.title: No Increased Stroke Risk Linked to Pfizer’s Covid Boosters, Federal Officials Say
item.description: An uptick hinted at in surveillance data was a mirage, the officials said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times
item.media:description: A booster vaccination clinic in Salt Lake City last year.
